# Kerbal Space Port Replacement Info Page

This page is a central repository of all useful information for people helping to create a community-run Kerbal Space Program mod hosting site.

See this forum thread: [forum thread](http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/71133-Community-Mod-Repository-and-The-Majiir-Challenge)

The thread is getting rather long, so I thought I'd create somewhere we could add information, both for reference, and to get new people up to speed without having ot trawl 20+ forum pages.

Nothing is set in stone yet, so if you have a better place to host this info, feel free to do so. Even betterm, ask me and I can provide you with the source (tables are annoying to copy).

##The Story So Far

OK, so Majiir noticed a while back that Kerbal Space Port was getting increasingly inadequate for the modding community's needs, so he announced a Challenge for someone to develop a new replacement, which he had the resources to sufficiently host.

What with the recent announcement that [Curse are taking over mod management](http://kerbaldevteam.tumblr.com/post/84927345579/kerbal-space-program-curse-com-partner-together-for) and [Kerbal Space Port](http://kerbalspaceport.com/) is being closed on the 30th May, interest has spiked in building a new mod hosting platform.

Currently, various efforts are being made by lone coders to build a site, which you can read about on the aforementioned [forum thread](http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/71133-Community-Mod-Repository-and-The-Majiir-Challenge).

* At the moment, [this site](http://www.kerbalstation.org/) is the most complete and visible effort (because it was made earlier)
* It has been [donated to the community](http://www.reddit.com/r/KerbalSpaceProgram/comments/24yufz/a_bit_ago_i_built_kerbal_space_station_a_quick/) by its author.
* Its github repo is [here](https://github.com/kerbalspaceprogram), and it's written in Ruby on Rails.



I'll make this page editable to interested parties, but in the meantime here's what I've gleaned from the thread.

## Brainstorming Notes Poached From RadGH

Sorry for not asking permission yet.


* Prominent Download link, above-the-fold
* Download statistics (php-ga?)
* Export download stats as raw data
* Search system
  * (searching Kethane should show Kethane first, not HexCans with Kethane models, etc)
* No moderation queue for new uploads, at least for trusted users
* Versioning - Keep old versions, remember what version they were for, etc

----

Mod meta data:
Mod Name
Author Name
Website URL
Author URL
KSP Version

----

Screenshots and/or Videos. Slider/Gallery? Lightbox? Must not push download button off screen.

Changelogs, based on versioning

License

Link to source
Link to donate
Link to forum thread

No commenting, or option to Disable commenting per-mod.

Mod review system? Thumbs up or down, like Steam, replacing comments. Will require flagging reviews as "incompatible" or "Incorrect install" to get rid of the "IT DOESNT WORK FOR ME"

Upvote only rating system, reputation system, decay?

----

Off-site downloads, but still tracking clicks. Consider that those mods may become 404, require captchas, or otherwise offer poor UX to our users.

Subscription to mod updates. RSS feeds. Push notifications? (There must be a third party service for all of these. Mailchimp integration?)

----

Do not force quality. Do not force semantics. Do not force required file structures.

Allow different licenses. Possibly require users to click "accept" to donwload, as a mod-specific setting? (I'm not a lawyer)

Flag for spam, offensive, etc. Moderation thing.

----

Good example of a similar repository, for reference:
https://www.npmjs.org/package/underscore

Multi-categorization

----

Possibly separate craft file upload, with mod dependencies

Categories and tags. Possibly "primary" categories which are limited, which your mod 

is mostly composed of.

----

Works with vX.XX to confirm if your mod works with what version

List mod dependencies

Read this at some point:
http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ericgu/archive/2004/01/12/57985.aspx

RESTful API like this:
